author: Mrster

author: belstar

text:
+yenk chauvaux
+Mrster

Amiga, of course. The use and abuse of samples in a tracked music was the trademark of amiga music. It is the frontier of chiptune music. It is no more an ADSR (attack, decay, sustain, release) matter, and nor a midi composition because the sampled sounds are infinitely richer than chiptune (although many musics had also chiptune sounds) or midi (although midi, chiptune and sampled musics have a common point: the tracker.)

But there are limitations : size of the file (sometimes, the game and the music must fit in a 3 1/4 disk!), the memory, et caetera.

However, Amiga was a beast for his era.
author: BixenteFabregas

text: +BixenteFabregas Yeah it has the trademark sounds of it, I just wondered if it was an arcade version or even the PC Engine or something, I wasn' t too sure about those.

author: DTMTroy

text: Tracks like this show me that my taste in music keeps evolving. I'll be honest, I used to not like Tim Follin's compositions that much, even if he's considered to be a legendary composer in the industry. Then I started composing music myself, actually analyzing the tracks I listened to and that's when I understood just how good Follin was with such limited hardware. Tim Follin's tracks are just so complex and imaginative, it makes for something very unique. It's not just about the melodies.
author: SupraDarky
